newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Bank Negara imposes new limits for motor insurance.
newsitem.headline: Bank Negara imposes new limits for motor insurance.

text.p: The Malaysian central bank said on Thursday that it will impose new limits on loading and "excess" for motor insurance from November 1 this year.
In a statement, Bank Negara said the limits are proposed pending a review of the tariff and third party classes of motor insurance.
The central bank said the new limits will be imposed to reduce the element of subsidy to third party insurance.
Third party insurance refers to an insurance policy which only allows other vehicles involved in an accident with the insured vehicle to submit claims.
Bank Negara said the limits imposed on loading will be determined on the basis of common underwriting criteria such as age of vehicle, driver's characteristics and on claims' experience.
Motor insurance loading refers to the additional premium charged on second-hand cars.
"It is only fair that a person who makes claims should pay a higher premium as compared to a person who does not make any claim," the statement said.

"The loading related to claims will only operate if a vehicle owner makes two or more claims during the preceding two years. Accordingly, the loading for comprehensive insurance, especially for a vehicle owner who makes no claim, will be reduced," Bank Negara said.
Caps will also be placed on "excess" applicable to claims. Excess refers to the amount a vehicle owner has to pay himself from a repair bill which he submits to the insurance company.
Bank Negara said it was limitting the excess to a maximum 2.5 percent of the insured value.
It said the excess applicable to third party claims has caused "considerable inconvenience to third party claimants in making recovery on damage to their vehicles".
It said in some incidents, claimants "have been unable to make any recovery at all due to the high excess applied to the vehicle owners who had caused the damage".
Bank Negara said an exercise to review the claims experience for different classes of vehicles and for different scopes of cover is currently in progress.
